posts.name: Carson
posts.cooked:
hello me and my teammate from team 2221 are conducting a questionnaire for feedback for a year school project developing a modular programmable controller platform for drivers. we would like feedback from the first community about interest and ideas!

Hello me and my teammate from team 2221 are conducting a questionnaire for feedback for a year school project developing a modular controller platform for drivers.

posts.name: bobbysq
posts.cooked: What does ‚Äúcontroller‚Äù mean in this context? Game controller? Motor controller? Robotics controller? PLC ?

posts.name: Carson
posts.cooked: driver controller. i went and change it to reflect that sorry i didnt think about it.

posts.name: Chris Herzog
posts.cooked:
The more context you can provide including maybe examples and the like (you suggest there are modular controllers and they are ‚Äúexpensive‚Äù - could you reference a few), the more likely you can get some actionable information.

A yes/no survey is cheap - meaning you‚Äôre not asking much so the resulting answer isn‚Äôt that valuable.

You might get some more actionable information if asked questions that provided more background or more focused responses like evaluating different proposals or methods or providing a place where people can provide feedback.

Asking what controller they are using will probably help give some context to their feedback as well.  One of the biggest drivers for folks to try something ‚Äúnew‚Äù is to capture what they don‚Äôt like about their current solution to identify areas you might want to address.  In the same vein, knowing what people don‚Äôt care about in regards to their current solution can help cut down what you‚Äôre trying to address.

One other thing to capture is whether the respondent is a driver and if so, how much experience do they have?  I‚Äôm not a driver but I‚Äôm interested in what the user interface to the robot is to help the programming team build control strategies that help the drive team work as effectively as they can so this could be a big deal.

I think you‚Äôre doing the right thing to start to collect information but just getting yes or no answers might not help that much.  Don‚Äôt be hesitant to go a little deeper to help establish what you‚Äôre trying to do and to get more meaningful feedback.

posts.name: Carson
posts.cooked: thank you for the feed back this is my first time making a survey like this . eventually i will update it with more detail and probably make another survey about it with more detail , but right now we are just trying to validate our problem by making a survey so mainly to see if this is a project that we should pursue. next time i get a chance i am going to update it. thank you

posts.name: Liam
posts.cooked: Would this look like a button board? An Xbox controller? What form might it take?

posts.name: Carson
posts.cooked: Right now we are thinking  individual components like thumbsticks and buttons that fit together like a puzzle with a central board. Ideally the goal would be to be able to use it in a xbox controller configuration and a button board configuration as well

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
Cool idea. Not the first time I‚Äôve seen something like this, but still interesting.

As students, my advice is the same as always: propose a product. Have fun showing off what you come up with. I‚Äôm interested to see what you learn.

If you are professionals, my word of caution: entering the market for the first as the low cost supplier is hard.

posts.name: Carson
posts.cooked: Thanks We are students and we want to work on this as a engineering capstone project
